special_features: Commentary by Peter Davison, Janet Fielding, Sarah Sutton, and Matthew Waterhouse
Now and Then - A look at the locations used in the making of this story
Stripped for Action - The Fifth Doctor - A look at the Fifth Doctor's comic strip adventures
Points of View - Barry Took airs disgruntled viewers' letters about the rescheduling of Doctor Who
Film Restoration - Before and after examples of techniques used during the restoration of the location film elements of this story

releases.details: Features a brand new HD film transfer.
special_features: Audio commentary by Peter Davison, Janet Fielding, Sarah Sutton, and Matthew Waterhouse
Extended Version - Part One with deleted sequences re-integrated

notes: The working title for this story was The Beast.
This is the first two-part serial of the 1980s.
Notable for Peter Davison actually playing cricket during the story, showcasing his love for the game.
The script was not well received by the main cast, citing weak narrative and stereotypes.

in_universe_mythology: George Cranleigh was thought to have been dead but was actually tortured and returned home in disguise.
real_world_cultural_references: The Charleston dance popularized in the 1920s.
The Doctor sings a song from the musical 'No No Nanette', which debuted in 1925.
items: Costumes for a fancy dress ball

continuity_notes: References to the Doctor's desire to be a train driver.
Nyssa mentions their recent part in the Great Fire of London.

plot.plot_summary: The TARDIS arrives in 1925 where the Fifth Doctor mistakenly participates in a local cricket match. Invited to a masquerade ball at Cranleigh Hall, events take a sinister turn as murders occur, leading to the Doctor having to unravel the mystery while navigating mistaken identities and a hidden past involving the host family.
